October 20, 2002: Fiction
THE LOVELY BONES, by Alice Sebold. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A 14-year-old girl
looks down from heaven as she describes what happens in the aftermath of her
kidnapping and murder.
FROM A BUICK 8, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $28.) An abandoned 1954 Buick
Roadmaster turns out to be a conduit to another, evil dimension.
NIGHTS IN RODANTHE, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $22.95.) After her
husband leaves her for someone younger, a 45-year-old woman finds romance in
a small town on the North Carolina coast.
BLESSINGS, by Anna Quindlen. (Random House, $24.95.) When the young
caretaker of an estate finds a newborn girl in a box, his employer, an 80-year-old
matriarch, decides to help him keep the baby.
THE MURDER BOOK, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Ballantine, $26.95.) The
psychologist-detective Alex Delaware helps a friend in the Los Angeles Police
Department probe the long-ago murder of a young woman.
RED RABBIT, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $28.95.) In the early 1980's, when he is a
C.I.A. novice, Jack Ryan acts to thwart a Soviet plot against the pope.
THE NEW JEDI ORDER: DESTINY'S WAY, by Walter Jon Williams. (Lucas/Del
Rey/Ballantine, $25.95.) A new "Star Wars" novel.
WAR OF HONOR, by David Weber. (Baen, $26.) A science fiction novel in which
interstellar war breaks out just when things seem relatively peaceful.
NO ONE TO TRUST, by Iris Johansen. (Bantam, $25.95.) A woman who was
trained as an assassin by the military is on the run from a ruthless killer.
TRICKY BUSINESS, by Dave Barry. (Putnam, $24.95.) Gamblers, murderers and
a classic-rock cover band come together on a Florida cruise ship.
KILLJOY, by Julie Garwood. (Ballantine, $25.95.) A crime analyst for the F.B.I.
tries to rescue her aunt from the clutches of a fiendishly brilliant killer.
DUNE: THE BUTLERIAN JIHAD, by Brian Herbert and Kevin J. Anderson.
(Tor/Tom Doherty, $27.95.) A prequel to Frank Herbert's science fiction series.
KENTUCKY SUNRISE, by Fern Michaels. (Kensington, $24.) An accomplished
horsewoman tries to produce another Derby winner from her family's stables.
SHRINK RAP, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $24.95.) The private investigator
Sunny Randall is hired as a bodyguard to protect a best-selling author.
LULLABY, by Chuck Palahniuk. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A reporter sets out to
October 20, 2002
Non-Fiction
LEADERSHIP, by Rudolph W. Giuliani with Ken Kurson. (Miramax/Hyperion,
$25.95.) The former mayor of New York discusses what it takes to be a leader and
addresses subjects like the crime rate and 9/11.
LET'S ROLL! by Lisa Beamer with Ken Abraham. (Tyndale, $24.99.) A memoir by
the wife of Todd Beamer, one of the passengers on United Flight 93 on Sept. 11.
LONGITUDES AND ATTITUDES, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus &
Giroux, $26.) Notes and reflections on Sept. 11, by a columnist for The Times.
LET FREEDOM RING, by Sean Hannity. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $25.95.)
The conservative commentator surveys domestic and foreign issues after Sept.
ABRAHAM, by Bruce Feiler. (Morrow, $23.95.) Judaism, Christianity and Islam as
seen through the story of one man.
SANDY KOUFAX, by Jane Leavy. (HarperCollins, $23.95.) A biography of the
great pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers.
SLANDER, by Ann Coulter. (Crown, $25.95.) The lawyer and pundit enumerates
"liberal lies about the American right."
NOTHING IS IMPOSSIBLE, by Christopher Reeve. (Random House, $19.95.)
Meditations on overcoming hardships by the actor who was paralyzed after a
horseback-riding accident seven years ago.
BLUE LATITUDES, by Tony Horwitz. (Holt, $26.) The author of "Confederates in
the Attic" recreates Capt. James Cook's three voyages to the Pacific in the 18th
century.
THE BLANK SLATE, by Steven Pinker. (Viking, $27.95.) A critique of the idea that
we are shaped primarily by experience rather than by our genes.
A MIND AT A TIME, by Mel Levine. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A professor of
pediatrics examines the learning patterns of children, and the various ways in
which parents and other adults can help them succeed.
GOOD TO GREAT, by Jim Collins. (HarperBusiness, $27.50.) Why some
companies thrive and others do not.
LIVE FROM NEW YORK, by Tom Shales and James Andrew Miller. (Little, Brown,
$25.95.) An oral history of "Saturday Night Live."
THE BITCH IN THE HOUSE, edited by Cathi Hanauer. (Morrow, $23.95.) Twenty-
six essays by women writers about "sex, solitude, work, motherhood and
marriage."
